turns.content:
I apologize for the incomplete sentence in my previous message. Here is the complete list of hypothetical substances and concepts that were once believed to exist but were later disproven or found to be unnecessary, with the term "aether wind" consolidated into the first item:

* Aether/ether/luminiferous ether/luminiferous aether/aether wind: a hypothetical substance that was once believed to be the medium through which light traveled or propagated, or a hypothetical substance that was believed to be responsible for the motion of celestial objects. It was thought to be an invisible, weightless substance that filled all of space and that was necessary for the transmission of light or the movement of celestial objects. However, the existence of this substance was later disproven by experiments such as the Michelson-Morley experiment, which showed that the speed of light was the same in all directions, regardless of the motion of the observer.
* Caloric: a hypothetical substance that was once believed to be the medium through which heat was transmitted, but its existence was later disproven by the work of James Joule.
* Phlogiston: a hypothetical substance that was once believed to be present in all combustible materials and released during burning, but its existence was later disproven by the work of Antoine Lavoisier and other scientists.
* Orgone: a hypothetical form of energy that is believed to be associated with the life force or vital energy of living things, often used in the context of spiritual or metaphysical beliefs and practices.
* Chi: a hypothetical form of energy that is believed to be associated with the life force or vital energy of living things, often used in the context of spiritual or metaphysical beliefs and practices.
* Prana: a hypothetical form of energy that is believed to be associated with the life force or vital energy of living things, often used in the context of spiritual or metaphysical beliefs and practices.
* Vital momentum: a hypothetical
Carry on from "Vital momentum: a hypothetical ... " finish the item and go on to the next. Don't go right back to the beginning again.

Certainly. Here is the rest of the list of hypothetical substances and concepts that were once believed to exist but were later disproven or found to be unnecessary, with the term "aether wind" consolidated into the first item:

* Vital momentum: a hypothetical form of energy that is believed to be associated with the life force or vital energy of living things, often used in the context of spiritual or metaphysical beliefs and practices.
* Elan vital: a hypothetical form of energy that is believed to be associated with the life force or vital energy of living things, coined by French philosopher Henri Bergson in the context of his philosophical ideas about the nature of life and consciousness.
* The four humors: In ancient Greek and Roman medicine, it was believed that the body contained four fluid-like substances called "humors" (blood, phlegm, yellow bile, and black bile) that were responsible for maintaining health and causing disease.
* The plenitude principle: The plenitude principle was a philosophical idea that stated that everything that is logically possible must exist in some form.
* The vital force: The vital force was a hypothetical substance that was once believed to be responsible for the maintenance of life and the manifestation of living qualities in organisms.

I hope this helps. Let me know if you have any further questions.
That is very helpful. I now have a list of nonexistent substances to work with in Midjourney.

I'm glad that I could help. If you have any further questions about these hypothetical substances or about any other scientific or philosophical concepts, please don't hesitate to ask. I'm here to help.
Do Plato or Pythagoras have any proposed fictional substances?

Plato and Pythagoras were ancient Greek philosophers who made significant contributions to the development of Western philosophy and mathematics. While they did not propose any hypothetical substances that were specifically fictional in nature, they did propose various philosophical ideas and concepts that have been influential in the development of Western thought.

Plato, for example, proposed the concept of "Forms" or "Ideas," which he believed to be eternal, unchanging, and perfect abstractions that exist independently of the material world. He also proposed the concept of the "soul," which he believed to be immortal and separate from the body, and the concept of "recollection," which he believed to be the process by which the soul remembers knowledge that it has acquired before birth.

Pythagoras, on the other hand, is known for his contributions to mathematics, particularly his theorem stating that in a right triangle, the square of the length of the hypotenuse (the side opposite the right angle) is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides. He also believed in the concept of "harmony" and the idea that the universe is governed by mathematical principles.

While these concepts and ideas were not specifically proposed as hypothetical substances in the way that the items on the list you provided earlier were, they have had a significant influence on the development of Western thought and continue to be studied and debated by philosophers and scholars today.
